ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Literature review, data collection and analysis, peer review (of selected weekly readings), and research writing
This course was useful to learn how to structure an academic research paper, and provided a survey understanding of issues relating to business in politics

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think quizzing students on readings via Kahoot is not the best way to assess students. There is a participation grade, especially in seminars, because that itself already represents how much students have read the weekly material to engage with the course. I didn't like how the seminar time itself was mainly a lecture, with sparse opportunity for students to talk and actually SHOW that they did read the material, and instead have that be assessed with a quiz that was not perfect in its execution. There were times where I couldn't get in the room for a bit, or when I couldn't click on an answer which I presume is because of poor connectivity issues at home, so I would much rather have a mid-term assessment instead of weekly Kahoot quizzes. Besides, students should have a chance to ask questions, go through that week's material, and better understand what the readings were about/their significance AND THEN be assessed. I frankly have never seen a format in which students were assessed before they had a chance to go through the materials with the professor. And again, if the point was to make sure we did the readings, then use section time to evaluate how much we've read by measuring our participation!

This course fell short in the discussions for me. I would have loved to engage more critically with the assigned readings, but the readings themselves were carefully selected and interesting to read. The Kahoot quizzes each week were also frustrating as they were only reading checks but not useful in better understanding the readings since the questions mostly revolved around minor details of the studies.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall didn't enjoy the online experience. But that is something the professor can't control.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think there are some improvements needed before I can confidently recommend this course to another student. Please refer to comments above.
